title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Near the mouth of the river Garry, which discharges itself into this loch, are the ruins of Invergarry Castle, the ancient gathering place of the clan JMacdonell.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Invergarry Inn is large and comfortable, and the innkeeper has the right of fishing in the river Garry.

title: Ghosts I have seen and other psychic experiences,

title: Ghosts I have seen and other psychic experiences,
author: Tweedale, Violet

title: Ghosts I have seen and other psychic experiences,

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: The hills on both sides approach very near, and descend in rugged precipices to the deep channel of the little river Garry.

title: Letters of Thomas Gray.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " It must be Lag himself from the Garry- horn," I thought; " he will be at his old work of pursuing the wanderers with bloodhound and troop-horse."

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: And who that ever was there does not remember the wonderful ball that closed the Athole Gathering, when delicate London giids were endued with miraculous spunk, when reel succeeded reel like the waves of the sea, — all innocent, and all happy, and all light of heel, — and when the jocund morn, far up in heaven, saw them " doun by the Tummel and banks o' the Garry," or across into Lochaber by the grim Ben Aulder and utmost Dalnaspidal.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: In the afternoon we proceeded by a stageof sixteen miles to Tummell Bridge Inn,retracing our way to the pass of Killicrankie,then turning down by a steep descent on theright, and crossing the river Garry by abridge, spanning high in air the two precipitous walls of rock, by which its waters areconfined to their dark, deep, channel.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: An hour ago these Avaters were pouring through the narroAv Passof Killiecrankie, by the foot of Ben Vrackie, and under the Bridge ofGarry and the dark Avoods of Faskally; and their coldness and theirlimpid clearness as they rush here into the profounder Tay speak yetof their mountain birth.

title: Observations in Europe, principally in France and Great Britain
author: Durbin, John Price.
snippet: Next day we drove to Dunkeld, left our luggage atthe Queen's Arms Hotel, and ascended to Blair Athol,seventeen miles, to see the famous Pass of Killicrankie,through which the Garry runs to join the Tummel, amile below.
